invalid UTF-8 byte sequence causes misdetection of encoding

note.body:
I think the error there is getting muxed up potentially due to IO streams being different on Flatpak. We might need to translate error codes better in GSV.

It could be a number of things. I didn't look at the invalid sequence, but it could be as simple as having `0x00` rather than the two-byte variant of `0xc0 0x00`.

target_title: invalid UTF-8 byte sequence causes misdetection of encoding

note.body:
> Hrmm, even when I try to open this with gedit it will fail to load completely due to an invalid byte sequence.

I am not an expert in character encodings. What means "invalid byte sequence" here? By setting `encoding='utf8'` in the write, am I not writing all data `utf8` encoded?

> The workaround, at least for now, since this isn't actually valid in any encoding, is that you use the open dialog and select `UTF-8` instead of `Automatically Detect`.

Indeed, this works at first. But then it is showing me:

![image](/uploads/6ea672a521242df307f5ee2be525303d/image.png)

I can still see and edit the file. So this errors is misleading.

> You'll still get the fallback conversion for the invalid UTF-8 byte sequence, but at least you can open/edit it.

I think this is fine. This is what other text editors do, too, and at least you can view and edit the file.

target_title: invalid UTF-8 byte sequence causes misdetection of encoding

target_title: Add SQL dialect

note.body:
Ah, it shoud be fixed immediately, the mime type seems that make a new one easyly, but the file extension(glob) not yet ready, any suggestion?
```
// Exist mime type and extenstion found the internet
text/x-sql                          .sql
application/sql                     .sql
application/x-sql                   .sql
application/x-sqlite2               .sqlite2    SQLite2 database
application/x-sqlite3               .sqlite3    SQLite3 database
application/vnd.sqlite3             .sqlite3    SQLite3 database
application/x-kexiproject-sqlite    .kexi       Kexi SQLite database file
application/x-kexiproject-sqlite2   .kexi       Kexi SQLite2 database file
application/x-kexiproject-sqlite3   .kexi       Kexi SQLite3 database file

// Suggest mime type and extenstion
text/x-sql-db2                      .db2        DB2 SQL file
text/x-sql-sqlite                   .sqlite     SQLite SQL file
text/x-sql-mysql                    .mysql      MySQL SQL file
text/x-sql-mariadb                  .mariadb    MariaDB SQL file
text/x-sql-postgresql               .pgsql      PostgreSQL SQL file
text/x-sql-sqlserver                .sqlserver  SQL Server SQL file
text/x-sql-oracle                   .oracle     SQL Server SQL file
```

target_title: buffer: implement sort deduplication using GHashTable

note.body:
On Win32, the test fails because `collate` doesn't work the same way there.

```
# Test case '\303\211
E\314\201
\303\211
E\314\201
' with flags 0x4
not ok /Buffer/sort-lines - GtkSourceView:ERROR:../testsuite/test-buffer.c:272:do_test_sort_lines: assertion failed (changed == expected): ("E\314\201
\303\211
" == "\303\211
E\314\201
")
```

With that patch, both Linux and Win32 work: [gsv_sort_tc.patch](/uploads/43fa442f5e56b774cc00a87b7ad73efd/gsv_sort_tc.patch)

note.body:
If y'all could test out https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtksourceview/-/merge_requests/381 that would help me out.

The goal there is to fix the issue here without introducing any new API or changing default behavior.

target_title: buffer: implement sort deduplication using GHashTable

push_data.commit_title: buffer: implement sort deduplication using GHashTable

target_title: Inconsistency in gtk_source_buffer_sort_lines

note.body:
This might be a bit crazy, but CPU-wise it shouldn't be too much more expensive. What if we keep the collate key in a hashtable and deduplicate on that rather than the previous line?

That way we don't introduce any new API, and memory bandwidth wise things don't change much (since you only hash the new string, GHashTable keeps hashes around for re-use).

Besides, GHashTable scales way better than GtkTextView does anyway.

Then we don't need any new API and I can backport this to the stable tree too.

Inconsistency in gtk_source_buffer_sort_lines

note.body:
Sorting with `lines` won't work when a `column > 0` is set...

I created a MR !379 to add new sort flags, but I would personally prefer to make raw sorting by default, and collate on demand only.

target_title: Draft: buffer: add new sort flags

note.body:
I'm not super-fan of this current solution... Using `collate` by default brings a lot of side-effects, like broken case-insensitive sorting (see [commented-out testcase](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtksourceview/-/blob/gtksourceview-5-14/testsuite/test-buffer.c?ref_type=heads#L290)) and duplicates removing (see #386).

I would personnally be more in favor of making raw comparisons by default, and adding new flags like `GTK_SOURCE_SORT_FLAGS_COLLATE` and `GTK_SOURCE_SORT_FLAGS_COLLATE_FILENAME` to use collate when requested.

A default raw sort would be IMHO more consistent with what an user expects when sorting source code. But that will for sure break some others's workflow...

edit: I created !380 as alternative proposal

target_title: Draft: buffer: add new sort flags
Inconsistency in gtk_source_buffer_sort_lines

note.body: Mirroring on the deduplication side is fine to me. Particularly because if anyone is using GtkSourceView for huge list dedeplication they're already in for a world of pain.

target_title: Inconsistency in gtk_source_buffer_sort_lines

note.body:
I was thinking of a way to fix the problem without disabling `g_utf8_collate_key` (which is important for sorting, I think): change the comparison function so that instead of just comparing the keys (transformed strings), you first compare keys, and when they are identical, compare the raw strings. That is, sort on key then raw string.

Thus, similar strings (identical after `g_utf8_collate_key`) stay together, and within each such block, the identical raw strings stay together, so removing duplicates will work.

It should be easy to implement as the `lines` arrays has both, and the comparison function can see both, but currently uses only the `key` field.

Another advantage of this approach is sorting is more "canonical": with the current way, different raw strings with identical `key` are sorted more or less randomly, as `qsort` is not stable. By sorting also on raw string, they get sorted in a well defined order.

I think it's better to keep unique raw strings as you may not want to lose information: it may be important to know that `É` and `É` are not identical. An alternate way would be to sort on `key` and remove duplicates by comparing `key` as well, and then `É` and `É` are really treated as identical. But I think this should be done on purpose by the user, by normalizing strings before the sort - it could be done in gedit with a plugin, for instance, as it may be interesting, not only for sorting.

target_title: Inconsistency in gtk_source_buffer_sort_lines

note.body:
Another issue with `collate` is that its behavior is not the same on different platforms (Linux vs. Win32). A "raw" sort would be welcome to have something coherent in teams developing under different environments.

I actually started implementing something about that some months ago, with a new SortFlag. I'll try to finalize.

Inconsistency in gtk_source_buffer_sort_lines

note.body:
That does seem annoying!

I don't have time to work on this, but what I would accept from a merge-request standpoint would be the following as I don't want to break existing behavior by not using `g_utf8_collate_key()`.

 * Add a new `GtkSourceSortFlags` bit flag to denote that the raw bytes should be used for sorting
 * Abstract the call to `g_utf8_collate_key()` in the two places based on that flag.

It would be nice if we could get another flag for `g_utf8_collate_key_for_filename()` too since that can have some useful behavior for sorting with `.` and numbers.

note.body:
Thanks for moving. Maybe you're right and it depends on the language.
It seems that Perl-RE and PCRE are indeed defined to take the first match and are thus - unlike BRE/ERE - non-greedy.
Strange, but I guess this can then be closed, cause it seems it uses PCRE? Thanks, Chris.

target_title: Style Scheme: Allowed to load styles from gresources

note.body:
Rather than introduce all these conditionals at the exit points of the function, I think I'd rather all cases use `GBytes` (and then `text` can be `const char *`).

We require a new enough glib that you can change the `g_file_get_contents()` to `g_file_load_bytes()` after creating an appropriate `GFile` based on `filename` being a `resource://` uri or a path string.
